awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Single-molecule imaging of T cell recognition and signaling
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract
Huang; 1653782

T-cells are a type of white blood cell that circulate around our bodies, scanning for cellular abnormalities and infections. The research goal is to understand the molecular mechanism of T cell recognition and signaling, which determines the selection, development, fate, and function of a T cell. Existing T-cell studies cannot directly visualize and measure the dynamic interactions and signaling events with enough spatiotemporal resolution. The PI proposes to use single-molecule resonance energy transfer and light-sheet microscopy to address this immunology problem by measuring early T cell intracellular signaling kinetics.
 
The PI will integrate research within teaching and create a research-intensive learning environment to educate students at the interface of immunology and engineering through a new emerging discipline called immune-engineering. In addition, the PI will develop educational materials, demonstrations, and web tutorials to inspire students to explore new research areas, and develop novel technologies to drive the booming field of immune-engineering.

The research project will use Forster's resonance energy transfer (FRET) to study molecular mechanisms of T cell recognition and signaling. The PI will attach fluorescent markers to the membrane receptors of T cells responsible for recognition and signaling. Furthermore, the PI will visualize T-cell receptor conformational changes, quantify the role of CD4, and measure early T-cell intracellular signaling kinetics in-situ. Also, he will observe T-cell receptor (TCR) and CD4 binding to peptide bound histocompatibility complexes. This initiates T-cell recognition and signaling at the cell membrane; antigen recognition will trigger proximal TCR signal transduction.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
With the generous support of the NSF career award, we have successfully accomplished the original goals set for this award. Additionally, we have further expanded our proposed research and made significant achievements in related research fields. The supported research has resulted 12 high-profile publications and 1 patent application, trained graduate students, undergraduate students, and high school students, including 6 female URM students. Specifically:

Intellectual merit:

  1. We have accomplished the original goals set for this award: we have quantitatively determined the molecular mechanism of antigen recognition and signaling by T cells. We have published 7 primary papers on this including: (1) Sasmal et al., 2020. Cell Mol Immunol. DOI: 10.1038/s41423-019-0273-6. (2) Rosenberg et al., 2020 (B). Cell Systems. DOI: 10.1016/j.cels.2020.04.006. (3) Rosenberg et al., 2020 (A). J Vis Exp. DOI: 10.3791/59914. (4) Lee et al., 2018. Nanoscale. DOI: 10.1039/c7nr08673c. (5) Harrison et al., 2019. Front Phys. DOI: 10.3389/fphy.2019.00045. (6) Rosenberg et al., 2018. Curr Opin Chem Eng. DOI: 10.1016/j.coche.2017.11.006. (7) Zhao et al., 2018. Cell reports. DOI: 10.1016/j.celrep.2018.06.054.

 

  1. We further extended our study to measure single-cell metabolism by high-resolution imaging and machine learning. We published 2 papers in this extended fields: (1) Wu et al., 2021. Nature Metabolism. DOI: 10.1038/s42255-021-00390-y. (2) Harrison et al, 2021. STAR Protocols. DOI: 10.1016/j.xpro.2021.100807

 

  1. Due to the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic, we further extended our research to study SARS-CoV-2 and develop nanomedicine for treating COVID-19. Out research results were highly significant and have been broadly reported by CBS, FOX, WGN-TV and highlighted by JAMA. Our research resulted 3 significant publications in this extended field. (1) Chen et al., 2021. Matter. DOI: 10.1016/j.matt.2021.04.005. (2) Cai et al., 2022. Advanced Science. DOI: 10.1002/advs.202103240. (3) Pan et al., 2022. BioRxiv. DOI: 10.1101/2022.01.10.475725

Broader Impacts:

As a bioengineer fascinated by immunology, my vision is to dedicate myself to the development of a new emerging discipline called immunoengineering, which applies engineering principles and methods to quantitatively study and manipulate the complex immune system. I aim to develop a deep, quantifiable understanding of the fundamental mechanisms in immunology and to initiate new research directions by creating new opportunities in the highly interdisciplinary field of immunoengineering. Supported by this NSF career award, I developed and applied single-molecule imaging methods to quantitatively and precisely measure T cell recognition and signaling with high spatiotemporal resolution. Our research provided unique learning opportunities for students in a highly interdisciplinary area that covers biophysics, molecular immunology, biophotonics, nanobiotechnology and bioengineering. Our research also provided a broad knowledge and skill set that inspired new endeavors in immunological research, led to the identification of important immunological mechanisms and principles, advanced student understanding in fundamental immunology, and promoted the development of immunoengineering in our laboratory.

The NSF career award supported the research of four UChicago graduate students (Jillian Rosenberg, Devin Harrison, Guoshuai Cao and Yu Zhao) and two UChicago undergraduate students Fernanda Borja‐Prieto (URM) and Leandra Wilson-Patrick (URM). Also, supported by this NSF Career award, our lab participated in many outreach activities. In the past five years, our lab has participated in many research programs to promote the awareness and involvement of our research. For example, we actively participated in two major educational programs through our strong ties with the University of Chicago Comprehensive Cancer Center, the Chicago EYES (Educators and Youth Enjoy Science) on Cancer, and the ResearcHStart programs. Chicago EYES is a research training program for high school and college students, and the ResearcHStart recruits high school students from the Chicago and Urbana-Champaign areas to explore exciting careers in cancer research. So far, our lab has trained four students including Spencer Huynh, Summer Smith (URM), Roshni Patel and Dalya Kanani. Among these four trainees, Spencer Huynh (currently a pre-med student) won the highest honor at the ResearcHStart Summer Research Symposium poster competition and was interviewed by CANTV about his research. We also participate in other science outreach programs: (1) Scientific Inquiry and Research program. We mentored two high school students Jason Chen and Yatri Sutaria (URM) from the Illinois Mathematics & Science Academy to perform research in our lab. (2) Engineering Co-ops program. Our lab trained a college student Ashima Thusu (pre-med student). (3) After School Matters: our lab trained Janell Mason (URM) and Summer Smith (URM) to perform summer cancer research and (4) Leadership Alliance program. We trained college student Xariana Vales (URM) to perform research. Finally, our lab has actively participated in other important scientific educational programs to advocate our research to our local community, including (1) IME-Museum of Science and Industry Workshop, (2) the UChicago Careers in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (UCISTEM) program, and (3) IME-High School Education Program.


Last Modified: 04/09/2022
Modified by: Jun Huang
